desc: int_0^1 f(t)=int_0^1 tf(t) show there exists d such that f(d)=int_0^d f(t)
problem:
\begin{problem*}{}{}
  Let $f\colon [0,1]\to \RR$ be a continuous function
  satisfying
  \[
    \int_{0}^{1} f(t)\mathrm{d}t=\int_{0}^{1} tf(t)\mathrm{d}t
  .\]
  Prove that there exists $d\in (0,1)$ such that
  $f(d)=\int_{0}^{d} f(t)\mathrm{d}t$.
\end{problem*}
solution:
\begin{soln}
  Define $g\colon [0,1] \to \RR$ such that
  \[
    g(x) = x\int_{0}^{x} f(t)\mathrm{d}t
    -\int_{0}^{x} tf(t)\mathrm{d}t
  .\]
  Since $f$ is continuous on $[0,1]$, $g$ is
  differentiable on $[0,1]$ by FTC. 
  Note that $g(0)=g(1)=0$. So, by Rolle's theorem,
  there exists $c\in (0,1)$ such that $g'(c)=0$.
  Computing $g'$, we get
  \[
    g'(x)=\int_{0}^{x} f(t)\mathrm{d}t
  \]
  by using FTC. So $g'(c)=0$ implies
  $\int_{0}^{c} f(t)\mathrm{d}t=0$.
  
  Now define $h\colon [0,c]\to \RR$ such that
  \[
    h(x)=e^{-x}\cdot \int_{0}^{x} f(t)\mathrm{d}t
  .\]
  Similarly, due to FTC, $h$ is differentiable on $[0,c]$.
  Also, $h(0)=h(c)=0$ and hence, by Rolle's theorem,
  there exists $d\in (0,c)$ such that $h'(d)=0$.
  Computing $h'$, we get
  \[
    h'(x) = e^{-x}\cdot (f(x)-\int_{0}^{x} f(t)\mathrm{d}t)
  .\]
  Thus $h'(d)=0$ implies $f(d)=\int_{0}^{d} f(t)\mathrm{d}t$,
  as desired.
\end{soln}
